title: Coco Gauff

2023 }} '''Cori Dionne''' "'''Coco'''" '''Gauff''' (born March 13, 2004) is an American professional [[tennis]] player. She has a career-high ranking of world No. 4 in singles, reached on October 24, 2022, and [[List of WTA number 1 ranked doubles tennis players|world No. 1]] in doubles, achieved on August 15, 2022. Gauff won her first [[WTA Tour]] singles title at the [[2019 Upper Austria Ladies Linz – Singles|2019 Linz Open]] aged 15 years and 7 months, making her the youngest singles title-holder on the Tour since 2004. She has won three WTA Tour singles titles and eight doubles titles – three partnering with [[Caty McNally]] and five with [[Jessica Pegula]]. Gauff rose to prominence with a win over former World No. 1 and seven-time Grand Slam champion [[Venus Williams]] in the opening round of [[2019 Wimbledon Championships – Women's singles|2019 Wimbledon]]. Born to parents with [[NCAA Division I]] collegiate backgrounds in basketball and track and field, Gauff experimented with a variety of sports as a child. She chose tennis, inspired by the [[Williams sisters]] and preferring an individual sport. Gauff had success as a junior, earning a sponsorship to train at [[Patrick Mouratoglou]]'s academy in France. She began playing on the [[ITF Junior Circuit]] at 13 and finished runner-up at the junior [[2017 US Open – Girls' singles|2017 US Open]] in just her fourth ITF event, the youngest finalist in the tournament's history. She became the No. 1 junior in the world after winning the junior [[2018 French Open – Girls' singles|2018 French Open]] singles title over McNally. She also won a junior Grand Slam doubles title at the [[2018 US Open – Girls' doubles|2018 US Open]], this time partnering McNally. Gauff made her WTA Tour debut in March 2019 at the [[2019 Miami Open – Women's singles|Miami Open]] and won her opening match. She received a wild card into the qualifying draw at the 2019 Wimbledon Championships, where she became the youngest player in the tournament's history to qualify for the main draw. There she reached the fourth round, and each of her matches was the most-watched of the day through the first week of television coverage in the United States. Later that summer, still aged 15, she reached the third round of the [[2019 US Open – Women's singles|US Open]]. In 2021, she reached her first major final in women's doubles at the [[2021 US Open – Women's doubles|US Open]], and reached her first major singles final at the [[2022 French Open – Women's singles|2022 French Open]]. {{TOC limit|2}} ==Early life== Gauff was born on March 13, 2004, to Candi ({{Nee|Odom}}){{Cite web|url=https://heavy.com/sports/2019/07/coco-gauff-mother-candi-mom/|title=Candi Gauff, Coco Gauff's Mother: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know|last=McBride|first=Jessica|date=July 8, 2019|website=Heavy|language=en|access-date=July 10, 2019}} and Corey Gauff, both of whom are from [[Delray Beach, Florida|Delray Beach]], Florida.{{cite web |last1=Persak |first1=Mike |title=Delray's Coco Gauff, 14, stays grounded with family after winning French Open girls' title |url=https://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/tennis/fl-sp-tennis-coco-gauff-20180618-story.html |website=Sun-Sentinel |access-date=7 July 2019}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/life/wimbledon-wunderkind-cori-coco-gauff/|title=So who is Wimbledon wunderkind, Cori 'Coco' Gauff?|last=Cohen|first=Claire|date=July 3, 2019|website=The Telegraph|access-date=July 10, 2019}} She has two younger brothers, Codey who is four years younger and Cameron who is nine years younger.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/03/sports/tennis/cori-gauff-facts-bio-history.html|title=Cori Gauff: 10 Things to Know About the Newest Tennis Phenom|last1=Rothenberg|first1=Ben|website=New York Times|date=July 3, 2019|access-date=July 7, 2019}} Her father played college basketball at [[Georgia State University]] and later worked as a health care executive, while her mother was a track and field athlete at [[Florida State University]] and worked as an educator.{{cite web |last1=Bembry |first1=Jerry |title=Coco Gauff and family following familiar path to greatness |url=https://andscape.com/features/coco-gauff-and-family-following-familiar-path-to-greatness/ |website=[[Andscape]] |date=July 5, 2019 |access-date=July 7, 2019}} Gauff grew up in [[Atlanta]], and became interested in tennis at the age of four after watching [[Serena Williams]] win the [[2009 Australian Open]] on television. Her parents encouraged her to try many sports, including basketball and track.{{cite web |last1=Maine |first1=D'Arcy |title=Meet Coco Gauff, the 15-year-old who has everyone at Wimbledon talking |url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/27105815/meet-coco-gauff-15-year-old-everyone-wimbledon-talking |website=ESPN |access-date=7 July 2019}} She began playing tennis at age six and decided she wanted to pursue it as a career because it was an individual sport and because of her early success in winning the "Little Mo" eight-and-under nationals at the age of eight. Gauff recalled, "I wasn't much of a team person. I loved tennis. I was so-so about it in the beginning because when I was younger I didn't want to practice at all. I just wanted to play with my friends. When I turned eight, that was when I played 'Little Mo' and after that I decided to do that for the rest of my life."{{cite web |last1=Marshall |first1=Ashley |title=American teen Gauff impresses in junior Slam debut |url=https://www.usopen.org/en_US/news/articles/2017-09-05/2017-09-05_inside_the_del_potro_classic.html |website=US Open |access-date=7 July 2019}}{{cite web |title=Why 12-year-old Cori Gauff hopes she'll be the greatest of all time |url=http://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/18401434/tennis-why-12-year-old-cori-gauff-thinks-greatest-all |website=ESPN |date=January 3, 2017 |access-date=September 11, 2017}} When Gauff was seven, her family moved back to Delray Beach so that she would have better training opportunities.{{cite web |title=Coco Gauff Bio |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/players/player/328560/title/Cori-Gauff#bio |website=WTA Tennis |access-date=7 July 2019}}{{cite web |title=Cori Gauff, 13, Has Great Potential And A Greater Goal: Be The Goat |url=http://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2017/04/cori-gauff-13-has-great-potential-and-greater-goal-be-goat/65662/ |website=Tennis.com |access-date=September 24, 2017}} They initially lived with her mother's parents before getting their own house. While in Florida, she worked with Gerard Loglo at the New Generation Tennis Academy starting from age eight.{{cite web |last1=Kane |first1=Portia |title=Interview with Coach Corey Gauff |url=https://blacktennismagazine.com/interview-with-coach-corey-gauff/ |website=Black Tennis Magazine |access-date=7 July 2019}} Gauff's parents gave up their careers to focus on training their daughter. Her father later became her primary coach while her mother oversaw her [[homeschooling]]. Her father had limited experience playing tennis growing up. At age ten, Gauff began to train at the Mouratoglou Academy in France run by [[Patrick Mouratoglou]], Serena Williams's longtime coach. Mouratoglou commented, "I'll always remember the first time I saw Coco. She came over to the Mouratoglou Academy in 2014 to try out and she impressed me with her determination, athleticism and fighting spirit... When she looks at you and tells you she will be number one, you can only believe it."{{cite web |last1=Butler |first1=Alex |title=Cori Gauff, 15, makes historic Wimbledon debut |url=https://www.upi.com/Sports_News/2019/07/01/Cori-Gauff-15-makes-historic-Wimbledon-debut/5161561731627/ |website=UPI |access-date=7 July 2019}} He helped sponsor Gauff through his Champ'Seed foundation, which he created to provide funding for talented juniors who did not have the financial resources to afford high-level training.{{cite web |title=Cori Gauff, the Revelation of Champ'Seed |url=http://www.champseedfoundation.com/en/latest-news/2017-09-18-cori-gauff-the-revelation-of-champseed/ |website=Champ'Seed Foundation |access-date=7 July 2019}} Gauff continued to have success – winning the USTA Clay Court National 12-and-under title at age 10 years and 3 months – to become the youngest champion in the tournament's history. ==Junior career== Gauff is a former world No. 1 junior.{{cite web |title=Cori Gauff |url=https://www.itftennis.com/juniors/players/player/profile.aspx?playerid=100320577 |website=ITF World Tennis Tour |access-date=6 July 2019}} She entered the prestigious [[Les Petits As]] 14-and-under tournament in 2016 at age 12 and made it to the semifinals.{{cite web |title=Andreescu to Gauff: Ngounoue joins rich tradition at Les Petits As |url=https://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2019/10/les-petits-le-mondial-lacoste-gauff-nadal-andreescu-ngounoue-wta-future-stars/85447/ |website=Tennis.com |access-date=26 October 2019}} Gauff began playing on the [[ITF Junior Circuit]] at the age of 13, skipping directly to the highest-level Grade A and Grade 1 tournaments. She finished runner-up to [[Jaimee Fourlis]] in her third career event, the Grade 1 Prince George's County Junior Tennis Championships in Maryland.{{cite web |title=Fourlis Sweeps Girls Titles, Mejia Wins Both Boys Championships at ITF Grade 1 Prince George's County International Hard Courts |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2017/08/fourlis-sweeps-girls-titles-mejia-wins.html |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |website=ZooTennis.com |access-date=6 July 2019}} At her next event, Gauff made her junior [[Grand Slam (tennis)|Grand Slam]] debut at the [[2017 US Open (tennis)|2017 US Open]] and finished runner-up to [[Amanda Anisimova]].{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=Anisimova Downs Gauff for US Open Girls Championship; Wu Makes History with Boys Title; Danilovic and Kostyuk Claim Girls Doubles Crown |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2017/09/anisimova-downs-gauff-for-us-open-girls.html |website=ZooTennis.com |access-date=6 July 2019}} She did not drop a set before the final in either tournament. Gauff became the youngest girls' singles finalist in US Open history.{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=Americans Gauff and Anisimova Meet for US Open Girls Title; Geller and Wu to Decide Boys Championship; Wu and Hsu Claim Boys Doubles Crown; Stephens Beats Keys for Women's Title |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2017/09/americans-gauff-and-anisimova-meet-for.html |website=ZooTennis.com |access-date=6 July 2019}} After beginning 2018 with a semifinal at the Grade 1 Traralgon Junior International in Australia, Gauff lost her opening round match at the [[2018 Australian Open|Australian Open]]. She didn't enter another tournament in singles until the French, where she won her first career junior Grand Slam tournament title. She did not drop a set until the final, where she came from behind to defeat McNally in three sets. With the title, Gauff became the fifth youngest girls' singles champion in French Open history.{{cite web |title=Gauff edges McNally in all-American girls' final in Paris |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/gauff-edges-mcnally-all-american-girls-final-paris |website=WTA Tennis |access-date=6 July 2019}} A month later following another final win against McNally at the Grade 1 Junior International Roehampton, she became the No. 1 junior in the world.{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=June Aces; Gauff, Nakashima Win Grade 1 Roehampton Titles; Nanda, Mayo and Stearns Qualify for Wimbledon Junior Championships; McDonald and Isner into Wimbledon's Second Week |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/07/june-aces-gauff-nakashima-win-grade-1.html |website=ZooTennis.com |access-date=6 July 2019}}{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=Kodat, Vallabhaneni, Bicknell and Wiersholm Win ITF Junior Circuit Titles; Gauff Moves to Top Spot in ITF Junior Rankings; Altamirano, Pegula Take Early Lead in US Open Wild Card Race; Liu, Aragone Qualify for WTA and ATP Events |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/07/kodat-vallabhaneni-bicknell-and.html |website=ZooTennis.com |access-date=6 July 2019}} Gauff reached the quarterfinals in singles at the final two Grand Slam tournaments of the year. She fared better in doubles at both tournaments, reaching the semifinals at [[2018 Wimbledon|Wimbledon]] with partner [[María Lourdes Carlé]] and winning her first junior Grand Slam doubles title at the [[2018 US Open – Girls' doubles|US Open]] with McNally. Gauff and McNally defeated compatriots [[Hailey Baptiste]] and [[Dalayna Hewitt]] in the final, all in straight sets.{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=Seyboth Wild and Wang Make History at US Open Junior Championships; McNally and Gauff Capture Girls Doubles Title |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/09/seyboth-wild-and-wang-makes-history-at.html |website=ZooTennis.com |access-date=7 July 2019}} In September, Gauff represented the United States at the [[Junior Davis Cup and Junior Fed Cup|Junior Fed Cup]] with [[Alexa Noel]] and Connie Ma. The team reached the final against Ukraine. After Gauff won her singles rubber and Noel lost hers, Gauff and Noel won the Junior Fed Cup by defeating Lyubov Kostenko and Dasha Lopatetskaya 11–9 in a match tiebreak.{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=US Girls Win Second Straight Junior Fed Cup Title, Spain Claims Junior Davis Cup; Muhammad and Mmoh Capture Titles in Templeton and Tiburon |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/09/us-girls-win-second-straight-junior-fed.html |website=ZooTennis.com |access-date=6 July 2019}} Gauff finished the year with another Grade A title in singles at the [[Orange Bowl (tennis)|Orange Bowl]].{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=Gauff Comeback Ends with Another Orange Bowl Title; Finland's Virtanen Makes History with Victory over Khan |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/12/gauff-comeback-ends-with-another-orange.html |website=ZooTennis.com |access-date=6 July 2019}} She ended the season ranked world No. 2 behind [[Clara Burel]].{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=Burel and Tseng Named 2018 ITF World Junior Champions; Cressy Wins Tallahassee Futures; Racquet Club of Memphis, Site of USTA Girls Clay Courts, to Close |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/12/burel-and-tseng-named-2018-itf-world.html |website=ZooTennis.com |access-date=6 July 2019}} ==Professional career== ===2018–19: First WTA titles, top 100=== [[File:2019 Roland Garros Qualifying Tournament - 86 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright=0.9|Gauff at the [[2019 French Open]]]] Gauff made her debut on the [[ITF Women's Circuit]] in May 2018 as a qualifier in the $25K event at [[Osprey, Florida|Osprey]], where she won her first professional match.{{Cite web|url=https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Rising_Stars/55351/14yearold-cori-gauff-sets-another-milestone-in-her-goat-quest/|title=14-year-old Cori Gauff sets another milestone in her GOAT quest!|website=Tennis World USA|access-date=12 July 2019}} She received a wild card into qualifying at the [[2018 US Open (tennis)|US Open]], but lost her opening match 5 months after turning 14 years old.{{cite web |title=Cori Gauff |url=https://www.itftennis.com/procircuit/players/player/profile.aspx?playerid=100320577 |website=ITF World Tennis Tour |access-date=6 July 2019}}{{Cite web|url=http://baseline.tennis.com/article/76223/americans-struggle-day-2-qualifies-us-open|title=Americans struggle on Day 2 of US Open qualifying|website=Baseline|language=en|access-date=July 12, 2019}} In her first 2019 tournament, she finished runner-up in doubles at the $100K [[2019 Dow Tennis Classic|Midland Tennis Classic]] alongside [[Ann Li (tennis)|Ann Li]].{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=McNally Upsets Top Seed Peterson to Reach Midland $100K Final; Cressy Advances to Cleveland Challenger Final; Forbes Wins Grade 1 in Ecuador |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2019/02/mcnally-upsets-top-seed-peterson-to.html |website=ZooTennis.com |access-date=6 July 2019}} Two weeks later, Gauff played her next event at the $25K level in [[Surprise, Arizona|Surprise]] and reached the finals in both singles and doubles. Although she finished runner-up in singles, she won her maiden WTA title in doubles alongside [[Paige Hourigan]] against compatriots [[Usue Maitane Arconada]] and [[Emina Bektas]].{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=Wake Forest, Ohio State Advance to Men's D-I ITA Team Indoor Final; Redlicki Wins Tucson Title, Gauff Comes Up Short in Surprise; Opelka Captures New York Open |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2019/02/wake-forest-ohio-state-advance-to-mens.html |website=ZooTennis.com |access-date=6 July 2019}} In March, Gauff made her WTA main draw debut as a wild card at the [[2019 Miami Open|Miami Open]] and recorded her first WTA match win against [[Caty McNally]].{{cite web| title=2019 Miami Open: Gauff 'controls the controllables,' marvels in first WTA win | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2019-miami-open-gauff-controls-controllables-marvels-first-wta-win | website=WTA Tennis | date = 21 March 2019 | access-date = 2 July 2019}} She lost her next match to [[Daria Kasatkina]].{{cite web |last1=Kane |first1=David |title='I remember every match' – Kasatkina reignites Venus rivalry in Miami after tough 2019 |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/i-remember-every-match-kasatkina-reignites-venus-rivalry-miami-after-tough-2019 |website=WTA Tennis |access-date=6 July 2019}} After losing in the second round of qualifying at the [[2019 French Open|French Open]], Gauff qualified for the main draw at [[2019 Wimbledon Championships|Wimbledon]], after entering the qualifying draw using a wild card. She upset world No. 92, [[Aliona Bolsova]], the top seed in the qualifying draw, in the first round and defeated No. 128, [[Greet Minnen]], in the third and final qualifying round while only losing two games. Gauff also became the youngest player to reach the main draw at Wimbledon by qualifying in the Open Era at the age of 15 years and 3 months.{{cite web |title=American Cori 'Coco' Gauff becomes youngest Wimbledon qualifier in Open Era history |url=https://www.smh.com.au/sport/american-cori-coco-gauff-becomes-youngest-wimbledon-qualifier-in-open-era-history-20190628-p522c9.html |website=Sydney Morning Herald |date=June 28, 2019 |access-date=July 6, 2019}} In her main draw debut, she upset five-time Wimbledon champion [[Venus Williams]] in straight sets.{{cite news |last1=Clarey |first1=Christopher |title=Cori Gauff, 15, Seizes Her Moment, Upsetting Venus Williams at Wimbledon |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/01/sports/cori-gauff-venus-williams-wimbledon.html |website=New York Times |date=July 2019 |access-date=July 6, 2019}} She continued her run into the fourth round with victories over [[Magdaléna Rybáriková]] and No. 60 [[Polona Hercog]], saving two match points against Hercog. The hype surrounding her first round match win led to her third rounder moving to [[Centre Court]].{{cite web |last1=Tignor |first1=Steve |title=Coco Gauff is the youngest at Wimbledon, but she plays a grown-up game |url=http://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2019/07/cori-coco-gauff-magdalena-rybarikova-wimbledon-second-round-2019/83118/ |website=Tennis.com |access-date=6 July 2019}}{{cite web |title='It's pretty surreal how life changes': Gauff halts Hercog, sets Halep battle at Wimbledon |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/node/244248 |website=WTA Tennis |access-date=6 July 2019}} She was eliminated with a fourth round loss to eventual champion [[Simona Halep]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2019/jul/08/the-coco-bubble-pops-at-wimbledon-as-simona-halep-ousts-cori-gauff|title=The Coco bubble pops at Wimbledon as Simona Halep ousts Cori Gauff|last=Ingle|first=Sean|date=July 8, 2019|website=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=July 8, 2019}} All four of her matches were most-watched matches on [[ESPN]] on their respective days during the first week of coverage.{{cite web |last1=Nagle |first1=Dave |title=Wimbledon Viewership up 29%; Coco, Sport's Legends Provide Compelling Action |url=https://espnpressroom.com/us/press-releases/2019/07/wimbledon-viewership-up-29-coco-sports-legends-provide-compelling-action/ |website=ESPN Press Room |date=July 10, 2019 |access-date=July 13, 2019}} With this performance, Gauff rose to world No. 141.{{cite web| title=WTA rankings Update 2019: Halep returns to Top 5, Gauff soars | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/wta-rankings-update-2019-halep-returns-top-5-gauff-soars | work=WTA Tennis | date = July 15, 2019 | access-date = July 16, 2019}} Gauff played in one [[US Open Series]] tournament at the [[2019 Citi Open|Washington Open]], where she qualified for the main draw but lost in the first round.{{cite web| title=Gauff cruises into Citi Open main draw | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/gauff-cruises-citi-open-main-draw | website=WTA Tennis | date = July 28, 2019 | access-date = July 30, 2019}} She also entered the doubles event with McNally and defeated [[Fanny Stollár]] and [[Maria Sanchez]] in the final for their first career WTA title in their first joint WTA.{{cite news |title=Gauff, McNally win Citi Open doubles: 'The way we're playing, we can go as far as we want' |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/gauff-mcnally-win-citi-open-doubles-way-were-playing-we-can-go-far-we-want |access-date=August 4, 2019 |website=WTA Tennis |date=August 3, 2019}} At the [[2019 US Open – Women's singles|US Open]], Gauff wild-carded into the singles and doubles main draws. She continued her Grand Slam success in singles with two three-set wins over [[Anastasia Potapova]] and [[Tímea Babos]], both on [[Louis Armstrong Stadium|Louis Armstrong]].{{cite news |last1=Clarey |first1=Christopher |title=Coco Gauff Delivers Again, in an Electric U.S. Open Win |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/27/sports/coco-gauff-us-open.html?action=click&module=Well&pgtype=Homepage§ion=Sports |website=New York Times |date=August 28, 2019 |access-date=August 28, 2019}}{{cite web |last1=Tignor |first1=Steve |title=In A Tenacious Tug of War, Coco Gauff Brings Armstrong House Down |url=http://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2019/08/coco-cori-gauff-timea-babos-second-round-2019-us-open/84655/ |website=Tennis.com |access-date=August 29, 2019}} She was defeated in the third round by world No. 1 and defending champion, [[Naomi Osaka]].{{cite news |last1=Livaudais |first1=Stephanie |title='Coco, I think you're amazing' – Naomi Osaka and Coco Gauff's emotional moment after US Open clash |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/1445684/-coco-i-think-you-re-amazing-naomi-osaka-and-coco-gauff-s-emotional-moment-after-us-open-clash |access-date=September 3, 2019 |website=WTA Tennis |date=September 1, 2019}} In doubles, Gauff and McNally also won two matches, including an upset over ninth seeds [[Nicole Melichar]] and [[Kveta Peschke]].{{cite news |last1=Streeter |first1=Kurt |title=Team 'McCoco' Takes a Turn in the Spotlight |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/01/sports/tennis/us-open-coco-gauff-caty-mcnally.html |access-date=October 23, 2019 |website=New York Times |date=September 1, 2019}} They lost in the third round to eventual runners-up [[Ashleigh Barty]] and [[Victoria Azarenka]].{{cite news |last1=Di Costanzo |first1=Diane |title=Victoria Azarenka and Ashleigh Barty end Gauff, McNally run |url=https://www.usopen.org/amp/en_US/news/articles/2019-09-02/victoria_azarenka_and_ashleigh_barty_end_gauff_mcnally_run.html |access-date=September 3, 2019 |work=US Open |date=September 2, 2019}} Gauff entered two more tournaments following the US Open. Although she lost in qualifying at the [[2019 Upper Austria Ladies Linz|Linz Open]], she entered the main draw as a [[lucky loser]] and won the title, notably upsetting top seed [[Kiki Bertens]] in the quarterfinals for her first top ten victory.{{cite news |last1=Livaudais |first1=Stephanie |title=Bertens dodges Van Uytvanck, gets Gauff next in Linz quarterfinals |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/bertens-dodges-van-uytvanck-gets-gauff-next-linz-quarterfinals |access-date=October 11, 2019 |website=WTA Tennis |date=October 10, 2019}} She defeated [[Jeļena Ostapenko]] in the final to become the youngest WTA player to win a singles title since 2004.{{cite web |title='It's been an unbelievable week for me' – Gauff grabs first title, defeats Ostapenko in Linz |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/it%E2%80%99s-been-unbelievable-week-me-gauff-grabs-first-title-defeats-ostapenko-linz |website=WTA Tennis |access-date=27 October 2019}} With this title as well as a semifinal in doubles with McNally, she made her top 100 debuts in both the WTA singles and doubles rankings.{{cite web |title=Cori Gauff Rankings History |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/players/player/328560/title/cori-gauff#ranking |website=WTA Tennis |access-date=27 October 2019}} Gauff and McNally ended their year with a second WTA doubles title at the [[2019 BGL Luxembourg Open|Luxembourg Open]] over [[Kaitlyn Christian]] and [[Alexa Guarachi]].{{cite news |title=Gauff, McNally win second doubles title in Luxembourg |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/gauff-mcnally-win-second-doubles-title-luxembourg |access-date=October 20, 2019 |website=WTA Tennis |date=October 19, 2019}} ===2020: Australian Open 4th round=== Starting the year ranked No. 67, Gauff started 2020 playing at the [[2020 ASB Classic|Auckland Open]] in New Zealand. In singles she defeated [[Viktoria Kuzmova]] before losing to [[Laura Siegemund]] in the second round.{{Cite news|url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/tennis/118689712/teen-star-coco-gauff-loses-to-laura-siegemund-at-asb-classic|title=Teen star Coco Gauff fights back tears after losing at ASB Classic|date=January 9, 2020|work=[[Stuff (website)|Stuff]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210513101734/https://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/tennis/118689712/teen-star-coco-gauff-loses-to-laura-siegemund-at-asb-classic|archive-date=May 13, 2021|url-status=live|access-date=January 23, 2020}} Playing doubles with McNally, Gauff reached the semifinals, losing to eventual champions [[Taylor Townsend]] and [[Asia Muhammad]]. At the [[2020 Australian Open – Women's singles|Australian Open]], Gauff defeated Venus Williams in straight sets in the first round{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/live/tennis/50254773|title=Listen: Djokovic reaches Australian Open second round|date=January 19, 2020|work=[[BBC News]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210510144045/https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/live/tennis/50254773|archive-date=May 10, 2021|url-status=live|access-date=January 20, 2020}} and [[Sorana Cirstea]] in the second round, making it three straight Grand Slams where she reached the third round.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/tennis-live-updates-australian-open-tennis-day-three-at-melbourne-park/RCLWVU2D7COPNLA6GVWAUSH6EU/|title=Tennis: Live updates: Australian Open tennis, day three at Melbourne Park|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]}} She defeated defending champion Osaka{{Cite news|url=https://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/staggering-awkwardness-in-naomi-osakas-australian-open-implosion/AOVPLP7IL6JWMCT3DN2WX4XCII/|title=Staggering awkwardness in Naomi Osaka's Australian Open 'implosion'|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210510143829/https://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/tennis-live-updates-australian-open-tennis-day-three-at-melbourne-park/RCLWVU2D7COPNLA6GVWAUSH6EU/|archive-date=May 10, 2021|url-status=live|access-date=March 25, 2021}}{{cite news |title=Tennis: Coco Gauff sets up showdown with Naomi Osaka at Australian Open |url=https://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=12302673 |access-date=19 July 2021 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |date=23 January 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200128214410/https://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=12302673 |archive-date=January 28, 2020 |url-status=dead }} in the third, becoming the youngest player to defeat a top-5 player since [[Jennifer Capriati]] beat [[Gabriela Sabatini]] at the [[1991 US Open – Women's singles|1991 US Open]]. In the fourth round, she lost to the eventual champion, [[Sofia Kenin]], in three sets. This was her second of three majors she had played where she made it to the second week.{{cite news |last1=Alexander |first1=Blayne |title=Coco Gauff knocked out of Australian Open by fellow American Sofia Kenin |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/sports/coco-gauff-knocked-out-australian-open-sofia-kenin-n1123206 |access-date=January 27, 2020 |work=[[NBC News]] |date=January 26, 2020}} In doubles, Gauff and McNally recorded their best result in a Grand Slam championship to date, reaching the quarterfinals before falling to second seeds and eventual champions, [[Kristina Mladenovic]] and [[Tímea Babos]], in two sets.{{Cite news |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/1590901/babos-mladenovic-prove-too-good-for-gauff-mcnally-in-melbourne-doubles |title=Babos, Mladenovic prove too good for Gauff, McNally in Melbourne doubles |work=WTA Tennis |access-date=January 28, 2020}} On the resumption of the WTA Tour following the [[COVID-19]] pause, Gauff beat two top-50 players at the [[Top Seed Open|Lexington Challenger]] before losing in straight sets to world No. 49, [[Jennifer Brady]]. At the Western and Southern Open, played in New York, Gauff lost in the first round to world No. 21, [[Maria Sakkari]]. At the [[2020 US Open – Women's singles|US Open]], Gauff was defeated in the first round by [[Anastasija Sevastova]].{{Cite news |url=https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/us-open/2020/rising-star-cori-gauff-loses-in-first-round-at-us-open-i-ve-still-got-a-lot-to-learn_sto7860265/story.shtml |title=Cori Gauff loses in first round at US Open – 'I've still got a lot to learn' |work=eurosport.com |access-date=1 September 2020}} As the tour moved onto clay Gauff, ranked 53, beat world No. 34, [[Ons Jabeur]], in the first round of the [[Internazionali BNL d'Italia|Italian Open]] before losing to two-time Grand Slam champion [[Garbiñe Muguruza]]. At the [[2020 French Open – Women's singles|French Open]], Gauff defeated the ninth seed and world No. 13, [[Johanna Konta]], in the first round, but went on to lose to eventual quarterfinalist [[Martina Trevisan]] in a second-round match in which Gauff hit 19 double faults. It was the first time Gauff lost to a player outside the top 100 since she had lost to [[Tamara Korpatsch]] in the second round in qualifying at the [[Linz Open]]. The final stages of the 2020 season saw Gauff take a wild card into the qualifying draw at the [[Ostrava Open]]. Gauff qualified for the main draw and was defeated by world No. 12, [[Aryna Sabalenka]], in the second round. ===2021: Top 20, first major singles quarterfinal & doubles final=== [[File:Gauff RG21 (6) (51375375152).jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.9|Gauff at the [[2021 French Open]]]] Starting the year ranked No. 48, Gauff entered the [[Abu Dhabi Open]], a leadup event to the Australian Open. In the first round, she beat Norwegian [[Ulrikke Eikeri]] before falling in the next round to [[Maria Sakkari]].{{Cite news |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/players/328560/cori-gauff/matches |title=Cori Gauff – Matches |work=wta.com |access-date=22 March 2021}} At the [[2021 Gippsland Trophy|Gippsland Trophy]], another Australian Open leadup, she beat [[Jil Teichmann]] in the round of 64, before falling in the next round to [[Katie Boulter]]. In doubles, she and McNally entered the [[2021 Yarra Valley Classic|Yarra Valley Classic]] where they reached the quarterfinals. At the [[2021 Australian Open – Women's singles|Australian Open]], in singles, Gauff again beat Teichmann in the first round, but fell in the round of 64 to the fifth-seeded [[Elina Svitolina]], in straight sets.{{Cite news |url=https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/australian-open/2021/australian-open-2021-coco-gauff-s-game-too-big-and-so-is-the-expectation-around-her_sto8117322/story.shtml |title= Coco Gauff's Game Too Big–And So is the Expectation Around Her |work=eurosport.com |access-date=22 March 2021}} In doubles, she and McNally fared better, falling to Demi Schuurs and Nicole Melichar in the quarterfinals. At Adelaide, she was the top seed in qualifying, beating [[Francesca Jones (tennis)|Francesca Jones]] and the eighth seeded [[Kaja Juvan]] to enter the main draw. In a run to the semifinals, all of her matches ran three sets, beating qualifier [[Jasmine Paolini]], sixth seeded [[Petra Martić]], and compatriot [[Shelby Rogers]] before falling to second seeded [[Belinda Bencic]].{{Cite news |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/players/328560/cori-gauff/matches |title=Cori Gauff – Matches |work=wta.com |access-date=23 March 2021}} In doubles, she partnered with Canadian [[Sharon Fichman]], and they bowed out in the first round to [[Duan Yingying]] and [[Zheng Saisai]]. This run brought her to a then-career-high of No. 38 in singles.{{Cite news |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/rankings/singles |title= Singles Rankings – 03/01/2021|work=wta.com |access-date=23 March 2021}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/rankings/doubles |title= Doubles Rankings – 03/01/2021 |work=wta.com |access-date=23 March 2021}} She entered the [[Dubai Tennis Championships|Dubai Championships]], where she beat [[Ekaterina Alexandrova]], 12th seed [[Markéta Vondroušová]], and qualifier [[Tereza Martincová]] before falling to Jil Teichmann, in straight sets in the quarterfinals. This brought her to a career high of No. 35 in singles.{{Cite news |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/rankings/singles |title= Singles Rankings – 03/15/2021|work=wta.com |access-date=23 March 2021}} In the [[2021 Miami Open|Miami Open]], she played her first WTA 1000 event while seeded (as the 31st). After receiving a bye, she lost in a tight three-setter to Sevastova in the round of 64. In the doubles event, she and partner McNally won easily in the first round before beating the second seeded (and then top Porsche Race ranked) team of [[Barbora Krejčíková]] and [[Kateřina Siniaková]] in a tight three-setter to play [[Gabriela Dabrowski]] and [[Giuliana Olmos]] in the quarterfinals where they lost. In May, Gauff reached the first semifinal at a WTA 1000 in her career at the [[2021 Italian Open (tennis)|Italian Open]] due to then-No. 1, Barty, retiring with a right arm injury in their quarterfinal match.{{Cite web|url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2142284/gauff-through-to-rome-semifinals-as-barty-retires|title=Gauff through to Rome semifinals as Barty retires|website=Women's Tennis Association}} As a result, she entered top 30 for the first time. She then lost to the eventual champion, [[Iga Świątek]]. At the same tournament, she reached quarterfinals in doubles with [[Veronika Kudermetova]] but lost again to eventual champions, alternates pair Dabrowski/Olmos. In Italy a week later, Gauff won her second singles and third doubles (with McNally) titles at the [[2021 Emilia-Romagna Open|Emilia-Romagna Open]] in Parma. She became the youngest player to win both the singles and doubles titles at an event since [[Maria Sharapova]] won both titles at the [[2004 DFS Classic|2004 Birmingham Classic]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2153537/gauff-sweeps-singles-and-doubles-titles-in-parma|title=Gauff sweeps singles and doubles titles in Parma|website=Women's Tennis Association}} Gauff thus rose to new career-high rankings of world No. 25 in singles and No. 41 in doubles. Gauff became the youngest American to make her top 25 debut in nearly 23 years (Serena Williams, June 8, 1998).{{cite web |title=WTA rankings Watch: Gauff, Badosa reach career highs |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2159780/wta-rankings-watch-gauff-badosa-reach-career-highs |publisher=[[Women's Tennis Association]] |access-date=19 July 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210524151003/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2159780/wta-rankings-watch-gauff-badosa-reach-career-highs |archive-date=May 24, 2021 |url-status=live }} Seeded 24th at the [[2021 French Open – Women's singles|French Open]] (her first time being seeded at a Grand Slam), she beat [[Aleksandra Krunić]] and [[Wang Qiang (tennis)|Wang Qiang]] in straight sets, received a walkover when leading one set to love against 13th seed and Australian Open runner-up [[Jennifer Brady]], and beat 25th seed [[Ons Jabeur]] in just 53 minutes to reach her first Grand Slam quarterfinal. As a result, she became the youngest female player (17 years, 3 months) to reach a Grand Slam quarterfinal since [[Nicole Vaidisova]] at the 2006 French Open, the youngest American to reach a quarterfinal at Roland Garros since [[Jennifer Capriati]] in 1993 and the youngest American to reach the quarterfinals of any Grand Slam since [[Venus Williams]] reached the 1997 US Open final.{{Cite web|url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2167316/gauff-sakkari-clinch-first-slam-quarterfinal-showings-at-french-open|title=Gauff, Sakkari clinch first Slam quarterfinal showings at French Open|website=Women's Tennis Association}} Subsequently, Gauff was eliminated after losing in straight sets to the eventual champion, unseeded [[Barbora Krejčíková]].{{cite news |title=Kerber wins generation game to knock Gauff out at Wimbledon |url=https://www.news24.com/sport/Tennis/FrenchOpen/unseeded-krejcikova-reaches-first-grand-slam-semi-final-at-french-open-20210609 |access-date=July 5, 2021 |website=reuters.com |date=July 5, 2021}} As a result, she reached a new career-high of No. 23 on 14 June 2021. At [[2021 Wimbledon Championships – Women's singles|Wimbledon]], Gauff reached the fourth round for a second consecutive time defeating [[Elena Vesnina]] in straight sets in 70 minutes,{{cite news |last1=Maine |first1=D'Arcy |title=Two years after bursting onto the scene at Wimbledon, 17-year-old Coco Gauff advances to third round |url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/31744642/two-years-bursting-scene-wimbledon-17-year-old-coco-gauff-advances-third-round |access-date=19 July 2021 |work=[[ESPN]] |date=1 July 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210711140713/https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/31744642/two-years-bursting-scene-wimbledon-17-year-old-coco-gauff-advances-third-round |archive-date=July 11, 2021 |url-status=live }} and [[Kaja Juvan]] in straight sets in the third round.{{cite news |title=Coco Gauff matches 2019 breakout by reaching 4th round at Wimbledon again |url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/31755475/coco-gauff-matches-2019-breakout-reaching-4th-round-wimbledon-again |access-date=19 July 2021 |work=[[ESPN]] |date=3 July 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210711184645/https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/31755475/coco-gauff-matches-2019-breakout-reaching-4th-round-wimbledon-again |archive-date=July 11, 2021 |url-status=live }}{{cite web |last1=Kane |first1=David |title=Fast and furious: Coco Gauff's exponential improvements on display through a stunning first week at Wimbledon |url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/coco-gauff-american-usa-teenager-wimbledon-venus-results |publisher=Tennis.com |access-date=19 July 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210704000115/https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/coco-gauff-american-usa-teenager-wimbledon-venus-results |archive-date=July 4, 2021 |date=3 July 2021 |url-status=dead }} Gauff lost her next match to [[Angelique Kerber]] in straight sets, eliminating her from the tournament.{{cite news |title=Kerber wins generation game to knock Gauff out at Wimbledon |url=https://www.reuters.com/lifestyle/sports/kerber-wins-generation-game-knock-gauff-out-wimbledon-2021-07-05/ |access-date=June 9, 2021 |work=[[Reuters]]|date=June 9, 2021}} She also reached the third round in doubles with Caty McNally and as a result entered the top 40 in the doubles rankings at No. 38 on July 12, 2021. At 17 years old, she was selected for the [[2020 Summer Olympics]] in Tokyo becoming the second youngest American player after [[Jennifer Capriati]] competed at 16 and the youngest Olympic tennis player since [[Mario Ančić]] in 2000.{{cite news |title=U.S. Olympic tennis team named, including Coco Gauff |url=https://olympics.nbcsports.com/2021/07/01/usa-olympic-tennis-team-roster-coco-gauff/ |access-date=19 July 2021 |work=[[NBC Sports]] |date=1 July 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210718193251/https://olympics.nbcsports.com/2021/07/01/usa-olympic-tennis-team-roster-coco-gauff/ |archive-date=July 18, 2021 |url-status=live }} However, she tested positive for COVID-19 and was forced to withdraw.{{cite web |last1=McGrogan |first1=Ed |title=Coco Gauff, Roger Federer, Matteo Berretini and more withdraw from Tokyo Olympic Games |url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/coco-gauff-roger-federer-matteo-berrettini-and-more-withdraw-from-tokyo-olympic-/ |publisher=Tennis.com |access-date=19 July 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210718194119/https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/coco-gauff-roger-federer-matteo-berrettini-and-more-withdraw-from-tokyo-olympic- |archive-date=July 18, 2021 |date=13 July 2021 |url-status=dead }} She reached the quarterfinals at the Canada Masters in the [[2021 National Bank Open|National Bank Open]] edition in Montreal after a retirement and a walkover from [[Anastasia Potapova]] and [[Johanna Konta]], respectively.{{Cite web|url=https://www.tennismajors.com/wta-tour-news/gauff-gets-walkover-from-injured-konta-into-montreal-quarter-finals-449803.html|title = Gauff gets walkover from injured Konta into Montreal quarter-finals|date = August 12, 2021}} At the [[2021 Western & Southern Open|Cincinnati Open]], Gauff reached the second round. She won her first match against qualifier [[Hsieh Su-wei]] in straight sets, but lost to second seed and world No. 2, [[Naomi Osaka]]. At the [[2021 US Open – Women's singles|US Open]], she beat [[Magda Linette]] in the first round before falling to [[Sloane Stephens]] in the next. In women's doubles, Gauff and her doubles partner McNally stormed into their first Grand Slam semifinal without dropping a set and defeated the top seeds Hsieh and Mertens in straight sets in the quarterfinals.{{Cite web|url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/32173627/coco-gauff-caty-mcnally-beat-top-seeded-elise-mertens-su-wei-hsieh-reach-us-open-women-doubles-semifinals|title=Gauff, McNally knock off top-seeded doubles team|date=September 8, 2021}} They progressed to the final when their semifinal opponents, [[Luisa Stefani]] and [[Gabriela Dabrowski]], retired after Stefani sustained an injury during the first set tiebreak.{{cite news |title=Coco Gauff, Caty McNally advance to US Open women's doubles final |url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/32183811/coco-gauff-caty-mcnally-advance-us-open-women-doubles-final |work=ESPN |agency=Associated Press |date=September 10, 2021}} In the final, they lost to [[Samantha Stosur|Sam Stosur]] and [[Zhang Shuai]].{{cite news |title=Sam Stosur-Zhang Shuai top Coco Gauff-Caty McNally in US Open women's doubles final |url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/32197570/sam-stosur-zhang-shuai-top-coco-gauff-caty-mcnally-doubles-final |work=ESPN |date=September 12, 2021}} ===2022: First major singles final, singles top 5, doubles No. 1=== Seeded 18th at the [[2022 Australian Open – Women's singles|Australian Open]], Gauff lost in the first round against [[Wang Qiang (tennis)|Wang Qiang]] in straight sets.{{cite news |title=Australian Open 2022 – Coco Gauff Hits 38 Unforced Errors as She's Stunned by Wang Qiang in Straight Sets |url=https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/australian-open/2022/australian-open-2022-coco-gauff-hits-38-unforced-errors-as-she-s-stunned-by-wang-qiang-in-straight-s_sto8716244/story.shtml |work=Eurosport |date=January 17, 2021}} In February, she reached the quarterfinals at the [[2022 Qatar Total Open – Singles|Qatar Open]] by defeating [[Shelby Rogers]], [[Caroline Garcia]] and third seed [[Paula Badosa]]. In the quarterfinals, she lost to sixth seed [[Maria Sakkari]]. In [[2022 Qatar Total Open – Doubles|doubles]], she paired with billionaire heiress [[Jessica Pegula]] to win her first WTA 1000 doubles title, beating third seeded pair of [[Veronika Kudermetova]] and [[Elise Mertens]] in the final.{{cite news |title=Gauff, Pegula charge to doubles title in Doha |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2504816/gauff-pegula-charge-to-doubles-title-in-doha |work=WTA |date=February 25, 2022}} With the win, she climbed to a career high No. 10 in the doubles rankings on 28 February 2022. Gauff reached her first Grand Slam singles final at the [[2022 French Open|French Open]], defeating [[Rebecca Marino]], [[Alison Van Uytvanck]], [[Kaia Kanepi]], 31st seed Elise Mertens, [[Sloane Stephens]], and [[Martina Trevisan]] before losing to [[Iga Świątek]] in straight sets.{{cite web | url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/34013745/coco-gauff-reaches-grand-slam-semifinals-first-beating-fellow-american-sloane-stephens-french-open-quarterfinals | title=Gauff beats Stephens, reaches first Slam semi | date=May 31, 2022 }}{{cite web | url=https://www.reuters.com/lifestyle/sports/world-number-one-swiatek-beats-gauff-win-french-open-title-2022-06-04/ | title=Ruthless Swiatek crushes Gauff to clinch 2nd French Open title| website=[[Reuters]]| date=June 4, 2022 }} She reached the final in doubles with Jessica Pegula where they were defeated by [[Caroline Garcia]] and [[Kristina Mladenovic]].{{cite web | url=https://www.tennis.com/baseline/articles/doubles-take-roland-garros-draws-winding-down-womens-mens-mixed-upsets | title=Doubles Take: Roland Garros draws winding down }}{{cite web | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2639187/gauff-pegula-to-meet-garcia-mladenovic-in-french-open-doubles-final | title=Gauff, Pegula to meet Garcia, Mladenovic in French Open doubles final }}{{cite web | url=https://au.sports.yahoo.com/tennis-french-open-2022-coco-gauff-doubles-devastation-loses-two-finals-224951379.html | title=Coco Gauff suffers double devastation in French Open drama| date=June 5, 2022 }} As a result, she secured a new career-high of world No. 13 in singles and the top 5 in doubles. After winning her first two matches at [[2022 Wimbledon Championships – Women's singles|Wimbledon Championships]] as the 11th seed against unseeded Romanians [[Elena-Gabriela Ruse]] and [[Mihaela Buzărnescu]], Gauff lost in the third round to 20th [[Amanda Anisimova]] in three sets.{{cite web | url= https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/wimbledon/2022/wimbledon-2022-amanda-anisimova-rallies-from-a-set-down-to-stun-coco-gauff-and-reach-fourth-round_sto9015330/story.shtml | title= Wimbledon 2022: Amanda Anisimova rallies from a set down to stun Coco Gauff and reach fourth round |date=July 2, 2022 }}{{cite web | url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/34189933/wimbledon-2022-coco-gauff-first-grand-slam-title-wait-how-much-longer | title=Coco Gauff's first Grand Slam title will have to wait ... But for how much longer? | date=July 4, 2022 }} As a result, she reached a new career-high ranking of world No. 11, on 11 July 2022. Seeded sixth at the [[2022 Silicon Valley Classic|Silicon Valley Classic]], she reached the quarterfinals defeating [[Anhelina Kalinina]] in the first round, and next [[Naomi Osaka]] who saved seven match points.{{cite web | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2719604/three-takeaways-gauff-comes-through-wild-finish-to-beat-osaka-in-san-jose | title=Three takeaways: Gauff comes through wild finish to beat Osaka in San Jose }} In her quarterfinal match, she struggled with her serve and lost in straight sets to Paula Badosa.{{Cite web |last=Tennis.com |title=Paula Badosa defeats Coco Gauff in San Jose quarterfinals; Shelby Rogers tops Amanda Anisimova |url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/san-jose-paula-badosa-beats-coco-gauff-rogers-anisimova-kasatkina |access-date=2022-08-12 |website=Tennis.com |language=en}} At the [[2022 National Bank Open|Canadian Open]], she became the youngest player to reach back-to-back quarterfinals in Canada since [[Jennifer Capriati]] in 1990 and 1991. She beat sixth seed [[Aryna Sabalenka]], a day after ousting Wimbledon champion [[Elena Rybakina]], winning both matches in a third-set tiebreak. She lost to eventual champion [[Simona Halep]], in straight sets.{{cite web | url=https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/wta-montreal/2021/a-great-match-simona-halep-beats-tired-coco-gauff-in-straight-sets-to-advance-to-canadian-open-semi-_sto9082401/story.shtml | title='A great match' – Simona Halep beats tired Coco Gauff in straight sets to advance to Canadian Open semi-final | date=August 12, 2022 }}{{cite web | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2739372/by-the-numbers-halep-stays-perfect-vs-gauff-to-reach-toronto-semifinals | title=By the numbers: Halep stays perfect vs. Gauff to reach Toronto semifinals }} Seeded third in doubles at the same tournament she reached the semifinals with Pegula defeating fifth seeds [[Desirae Krawczyk]] and [[Demi Schuurs]]. Next they defeated [[Madison Keys]]/[[Sania Mirza]] in the semifinals and [[Nicole Melichar]]/[[Ellen Perez]] in the final to win their second WTA 1000 title together. As a result, Gauff became the No. 1 doubles player in the world.{{cite web | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2744053/coco-gauff-captures-world-no-1-doubles-ranking-with-toronto-title | title=Coco Gauff captures World No.1 doubles ranking with Toronto title }} At the [[2022 US Open (tennis)|US Open]], she reached the quarterfinals of this major for the first time with wins over 20th seed [[Madison Keys]] and [[Zhang Shuai]] becoming the youngest American woman to achieve this feat since 2009, when [[Melanie Oudin]] was 17.{{cite tweet|number=1566548895328509953|user=espn|title=Coco Gauff (18) becomes the youngest American woman to reach the US Open quarterfinals since 2009 👏 @CocoGauff |…|date=September 4, 2022}} As a result she guaranteed herself a top 10 debut in the singles rankings at world No. 8 after the tournament.{{cite web | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2781533/gauff-garcia-set-for-quarterfinal-clash-at-us-open | title=Gauff, Garcia set for quarterfinal clash at US Open }} Subsequently, Gauff was defeated by Caroline Garcia, in straight sets.{{cite web | url=https://inews.co.uk/sport/tennis/us-open-results-2022-coco-gauff-caroline-garcia-semi-final-draw-1837496 | title=US Open results 2022: Coco Gauff destroyed by 'fearless' Caroline Garcia to set up semi-final against Jabeur| website=inews.co.uk| date=6 September 2022 }} Seeded second in doubles, Gauff and partner Pegula were defeated in the first round by [[Leylah Fernandez]] and [[Daria Saville]].{{cite web | url=https://tennisuptodate.com/wta/fernandez-and-saville-make-doubles-debut-dumping-out-gauff-and-pegula-at-us-open | title=Fernandez and Saville make doubles debut dumping out Gauff and Pegula at US Open| website=tennisuptodate| date=2 September 2022 }} In October, Gauff became the youngest player in singles since [[Maria Sharapova]] in 2005 to qualify for the year-end [[WTA Finals]] championships. She and partner Jessica Pegula also both qualified for the doubles' championships. Gauff and Pegula are the first Americans since Serena and Venus Williams in 2009 to qualify for both the singles and doubles year-end championships. {{Cite web |date=October 20, 2022 |title=WTA Finals: Coco Gauff becomes youngest player since 2005 to qualify |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/tennis/63329154 |url-status=live |access-date=October 24, 2022 |website=BBC Sport}} ===2023: Miami Open doubles champion === Gauff started her 2023 season at the [[WTA Auckland Open|Auckland Open]] where she defeated [[Rebeka Masarova]] in the final in straight sets. At the [[2023 Australian Open – Women's singles|2023 Australian Open]], Gauff advanced to the fourth round where she lost to [[Jeļena Ostapenko]] in straight sets.{{Cite web |author=Dzevad Mesic |title='Dejected' Cori Gauff after surprise AO loss to Jelena Ostapenko: I had no answers |url=https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Tennis_Stories/127322/-dejected-cori-gauff-after-surprise-ao-loss-to-jelena-ostapenko-i-had-no-answers-/ |access-date=2023-01-23 |website=TennisWorldUSA.com |language=en}} At the [[2023 Qatar Total Open]], Gauff reached the quarterfinals after defeating two time champion [[Petra Kvitová]] in the second round.{{Cite web |title=Gauff bests Kvitova in Doha; Bencic pulls off comeback vs. Azarenka |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3065973/gauff-bests-kvitova-in-doha-bencic-pulls-off-comeback-vs-azarenka |access-date=2023-02-25 |website=Women's Tennis Association |language=en}} At the same tournament in doubles, Gauff and [[Jessica Pegula]] successfully defended their title defeating [[Lyudmyla Kichenok]] and [[Jeļena Ostapenko|Jelena Ostapenko]] in a three set match.{{Cite web |title=Gauff, Pegula successfully defend Doha doubles title |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3069435/gauff-pegula-successfully-defend-doha-doubles-title |access-date=2023-02-25 |website=Women's Tennis Association |language=en}} At the [[2023 Dubai Tennis Championships]], she reached the semifinals after defeating [[Madison Keys]] in the quarterfinals before losing to Iga Świątek.{{Cite web |title=Swiatek improves to 6-0 vs. Gauff to reach Dubai final |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3080620/swiatek-improves-to-6-0-vs-gauff-to-reach-dubai-final |access-date=2023-02-25 |website=Women's Tennis Association |language=en}} At the [[2023 BNP Paribas Open]] she lost in the quarterfinals to second seed and eventual runner-up [[Aryna Sabalenka]]. In [[2023 Miami Open|Miami]] she lost against 27th seed [[Anastasia Potapova]] in the third round. In doubles at the same tournament, she won her fifth overall and third WTA 1000 team title with her partner Jessica Pegula. They became the first all-American duo to win the Miami Open doubles title in 22 years after defeating [[Leylah Fernandez]] and [[Taylor Townsend]] in the final. {{cite web | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3134118/gauff-pegula-win-miami-open-doubles-5th-team-title | title=Gauff, Pegula win Miami Open doubles; fifth team title }} ==Endorsements== Gauff uses a [[Head (company)|Head]] Boom MP 2022{{Cite web|url=https://www.tennisthis.com/tennis-racquet-reviews/which-tennis-racquets-do-the-wta-pros-use/|title=Tennis Racquet Reviews {{!}} Tennis String Reviews {{!}} ATP & WTA Tennis Racquets & Strings List|website=TennisThis.com}} with 16 main and 19 cross [[Strings (tennis)|strings]]. She wears [[New Balance]] clothing and tennis shoes.{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/timnewcomb/2019/07/29/breakout-star-coco-gauff-gives-new-balance-fresh-momentum/|title=Breakout Star Coco Gauff Gives New Balance Fresh Momentum|last=Newcomb|first=Tim|website=Forbes|language=en|access-date=2020-01-20}} In October 2018, Gauff signed her first multi-year sponsorship contract, with New Balance.{{Cite news |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/10/31/sport/cori-gauff-new-balance-sponsorship-deal-spt-intl/index.html |title=Tennis prodigy, 14, signs multi-year sponsor deal |work=CNN |access-date=November 1, 2018}} At the [[2021 French Open]], Gauff wore a [[New Balance]] outfit of bold mismatched color splotches to contrast with the all white ensemble of doubles partner Venus Williams.{{cite web|url= https://wlmtennis.com/roland-garrosfashion-palette/|title= Roland Garros…Fashion Palette |date=4 June 2021|work=WLM Tennis|access-date=17 December 2021}} In March 2019, she announced a multi-year sponsorship agreement with Italian food company [[Barilla Group|Barilla]], which also sponsors [[Roger Federer]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kurtbadenhausen/2019/03/21/this-15-year-old-tennis-prodigy-will-make-1-million-in-2019/|title=This 15-Year-Old Tennis Phenom Will Earn $1 Million In 2019|last=Badenhausen|first=Kurt|website=Forbes|language=en|access-date=2020-01-20}} ==Personal life== Gauff's tennis idols are Serena and Venus Williams. "Serena Williams has always been my idol...and Venus," she has said. "They are the reason why I wanted to pick up a tennis racquet." Gauff first met Serena when she won the Little Mo national tournament at the age of eight, and later met her again to film a commercial for [[Delta Air Lines]] and at the Mouratoglou Academy. After defeating Venus at Wimbledon in 2019, Gauff commended Venus when they shook hands at the net. "I was just telling her thank you for everything she's done for the sport," she said. "She's been an inspiration for many people. I was just really telling her thank you." In a 2020 post on "Behind the Racquet," created by professional tennis player [[Noah Rubin (tennis)|Noah Rubin]], Gauff stated she had experienced [[Depression (mood)|depression]] and stress related to her sporting career. Her parents clarified that she was not diagnosed with depression in the clinical sense, and had not sought medical attention relating to her psychological wellbeing.{{Cite news|last=Clarey|first=Christopher|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/19/sports/tennis/coco-gauff.html|title=Coco Gauff's Emotional Struggles: What Her Parents Saw|date=2020-04-19|work=The New York
